awd_titl_txt: Creativity throughout the Curriculum: Educational Practices to Build the STEM Workforce of Tomorrow
awd_abstract_narration:
The nation's economy and security require an engineering workforce that can design, manufacture, test, and deploy effective solutions to urgent, complex problems. In addition to developing traditional engineering skills, this workforce must also gain skills in innovation and creativity. This project aims to address this need by investigating a new paradigm of engineering education that integrates the foundations of science, engineering, problem-solving, and critical thinking with training in creative thinking, which is the foundation of innovation. The project will design, implement, and evaluate an experiential training program to help engineering educators teach creative thinking skills in sophomore-, junior-, and senior-level courses. The project's long-term goal is to increase student engagement and retention through novel instructional practices that prepare an innovative engineering workforce. 

The intellectual merits of this project include advancing knowledge about how to train an innovative workforce, investigating how focusing on innovation affects the persistence of engineering students, particularly under-represented minorities, and creating a transformative approach to engineering education that will produce an engineering workforce that is prepared to tackle complex, interdisciplinary problems. Standardized instruments will be used to assess aspects of student creativity, including design self-efficacy, resistance to change, and changes in creative thinking. The project's broader impacts include national dissemination of the pedagogical approach via publications, conferences, and workshops as well as research that may inform engineering education efforts to broaden participation of under-represented groups in engineering fields.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project aimed to integrate creative thinking skills into engineering courses, thereby developing an engineering workforce capable of providing innovative solutions to complex problems. It sought to redefine engineering education by merging a foundation of science, engineering, problem-solving, and critical thinking with creative thinking training. In particular, we investigated how an emphasis on innovation influences the persistence of engineering students, particularly under-represented groups. Through the Creativity Academy we have created a transformative approach to engineering education that will enable the engineering workforce to handle complex, interdisciplinary issues.

The project has made a substantial contribution to diversifying the engineering field, with effects that have resonated beyond the confines of the University of Missouri. By integrating creativity training into engineering coursework, we've been able to foster a more inclusive and dynamic learning environment that welcomes and accommodates diverse thinking styles and problem-solving approaches. In particular, our focus on innovation has shown potential in increasing the persistence of under-represented groups in engineering, contributing to broader diversity in the field. As we have shared our findings and methods through various academic platforms, we are encouraging other institutions to adopt similar approaches, further amplifying our impact on diversifying engineering education at a national scale. Furthermore, by training faculty in evidence-based creative practices, the project has extended its influence from students to educators. This allows for a sustainable change in teaching practices that can continue to promote diversity and inclusion in the engineering field, even beyond the life of the grant.

By teaching creative thinking alongside traditional engineering skills, we have begun to blur the boundaries between engineering and other disciplines, thus broadening the appeal of engineering studies and careers to students with diverse academic interests. As a result, our project has not only transformed the educational experience at the University of Missouri but has also made a significant contribution to the broader engineering education community. It has laid a foundation for a more innovative, inclusive, and diverse engineering workforce of the future.

Our major activities involved running the Creativity Academy, providing professional development to engineering faculty members and offering training in evidence-based creativity practices for integration into engineering coursework. Additionally, we presented our findings at international conferences and the project has resulted in several publications contributing to the academic dialogue surrounding creative methodologies in engineering education. These publications span topics from understanding how early-career engineering faculty perceive the role of creativity in engineering education to analyzing student experiences of learning in creativity-integrated engineering courses.
